extraction_metadata.focus: Renfro family foundation 1638-1728 - earliest allied family in this file
extraction_metadata.notes: The Renfro family provides context for later Johnson-Renfro intermarriages. Symon Renfro arrived 1638, same era as earliest Johnsons at Chippokes Creek.

sources_to_add.author: Nugent, Nell Marion
sources_to_add.title: Cavaliers and Pioneers: Abstracts of Virginia Land Patents and Grants
sources_to_add.full_citation: Nugent, Nell Marion. Cavaliers and Pioneers: Abstracts of Virginia Land Patents and Grants, Vol. 1 (Richmond: Virginia State Library, 1934), pp. 86, 546.
Chester County, Pennsylvania, Will of John Renfro, dated 28 July 1727, probated between 28 July 1727 and 6 April 1728.

sources_to_add.volume: Pencader Hundred, New Castle Co, Delaware
sources_to_add.full_citation: Records of the Welsh Tract Baptist Meeting, Pencader Hundred, New Castle County, Delaware, 1701-1728, pp. 18-19.
Bedford County, Virginia, Will of Joseph Renfro, dated 14 November 1772, probated 25 March 1776.

sources_to_add.author: Renfro, Dr. D.O.
sources_to_add.title: Renfro Family
sources_to_add.notes: Tony notes this researcher 'tried to tie together information on ALL Renfro's'

documents.title: Jeremiah Dickenson Patent - 500 acres, Upper Chippokes Creek
documents.location_description: West upon upper Chippoeks Creek, beginning at Swann Baye
documents.transcription_excerpt: JEREMIAH DICKENSON, 500 acs. James Citty Co., 6 May 1638, p. 546. W. upon upper Chippoeks Cr., beg. at Swann Baye, joyning upon a Sw. Tuning E. into the woods. N. towards the river mouth &c. Trans. of 10 pers: Eliza. Flinton, Henry Hayes, Elias Jue, James Hayes, Robert Newton, Robt. Muxford, Sarah Henchley, Eliza. Hayes, Wm. Gage, Symon Roufe (or Symon Renfo.)

people.notes: EARLIEST Renfro in Virginia records. Transported by Dickenson.

documents.notes: This is the earliest documented Renfro in Virginia. Tony notes: 'First notes in Virginia of Possible Renfro as Jeremiah Dickenson is tied to JOHNSON research and land owners JOHNSON at Chippoakes Creek.' The Chippokes Creek area is where early Johnsons also settled.

documents.title: Welsh Tract Baptist Church Records - John Rontfro
documents.transcription_excerpt: John Rontfro of record in Delaware. He appears on pages 18 and 19 of records of the Welsh Tract Baptist Meeting, Pecander Hundred, New Castle Co, Delaware, 1701 to 1728. Citing: (1) Signers of the Confession of Faith, 1725 (2) John Rontfro..., Margaret Rontfro and The names of Such as has been removed from us by death..

people.notes: Member of Welsh Tract Baptist Church; signed Confession of Faith 1725
Listed in church death records; likely wife of John Rontfro

documents.notes: John Renfro was part of the Welsh Baptist community that included settlers who later moved to Virginia. This provides religious/community context.

documents.title: Will of John Renfro - Chester County, PA
documents.transcription_excerpt: More About JOHN RENFRO: Died 2: Bet. Jul 28, 1727 - Apr 06, 1728, Chester Co, PA. Residence: 1697, VA. Will: Jul 28, 1727, Chester Co, PA. Children of JOHN RENFRO and MARY UNKNOWN are: i. DAVID RENFRO, b. Abt. 1677. ii. JOHN RENFRO, JR, b. 1695; d. May 30, 1748, Edgecombe Co, NC. iii. JAMES RENFRO, b. 1698, Orange, Va. iv. ENOCH RENFRO, b. Aug 24, 1698. v. SUSANNAH RENFRO, b. Bet. 1698-1705. vi. JOSEPH RENFRO, b. 1700, VA; d. Mar 25, 1776, Bedford, VA. vii. CAPTAIN WILLIAM RENFRO, b. Abt. 1702, James City Co, Va. viii. JACOB RENFRO, b. 1715.
documents.notes: This will documents John Renfro's 8 children who dispersed across Virginia and North Carolina. Several children end up in Orange County and the Valley of Virginia where they later intermarry with Johnson and Looney families.

documents.title: Will of Joseph Renfro - Bedford County, VA
documents.transcription_excerpt: March 25, 1776 In the name of God, Amen: I, Joseph Renfro of Bedford County, and colony.... I give and bequeath to Mary, my dearly beloved wife... Also I give to my beloved son, James... Also, I give to my beloved son-in-law Moses Renfro... Also I give to my beloved son Mark Renfro, the north side of the land on Black Water... I have in the last part given or bequeathed to my son Joshua Renfro, an entry south side of Black Water... Administration was granted to the three older sons, James Renfro, John Renfro and William Renfro.

people.notes: Son of John Renfro; French & Indian War veteran
Tony identifies her as Mary Randolph

documents.notes: Joseph Renfro's will shows the family established in Bedford County by mid-18th century. Five of his sons served as officers in the Revolutionary War. The Black Water location is in Bedford County.

family_groups_to_create.name: Symon Renfro of James City County
family_groups_to_create.summary: Earliest Renfro family in Virginia. Symon arrived as a headright 1638, lived in James City County, went to Barbados c.1652, returned. His descendants spread to Pennsylvania, North Carolina, and the Valley of Virginia where they intermarried with Looney and Johnson families.

new_people_to_create.evidence: Cavaliers & Pioneers v1 p.86 - transported by Jeremiah Dickenson 1638; FindAGrave memorial 116563969
new_people_to_create.notes: EARLIEST documented Renfro in Virginia. Transported 1638. Went to Barbados c.1652, returned. Father of Robert, Simon, Hester, Symon Jr.

new_people_to_create.evidence: Listed as child of Symon Renfro in Tony's research
new_people_to_create.notes: Son of Symon Renfro. Married (1) Mary Evans, (2) Susan Holmes.

new_people_to_create.evidence: Welsh Tract Baptist records pp.18-19; Chester Co PA Will 1727
new_people_to_create.notes: Member of Welsh Tract Baptist Church. Residence in VA 1697 per will. Father of 8 children who dispersed across VA and NC. Will dated 28 July 1727, probated by 6 April 1728.

new_people_to_create.evidence: Named in John Renfro's will as mother of his children
new_people_to_create.notes: Wife of John Renfro (d.1728). Surname unknown.

new_people_to_create.evidence: Listed as child of John Renfro and Mary in Tony's research
new_people_to_create.notes: Eldest known child of John Renfro.

new_people_to_create.evidence: Listed as child of John Renfro; death date from Tony's research
new_people_to_create.notes: Son of John Renfro. Moved to Edgecombe Co NC.

new_people_to_create.evidence: Listed as child of John Renfro
new_people_to_create.notes: Son of John Renfro. Born in Orange Co VA per Tony's research.

new_people_to_create.evidence: Listed as child of John Renfro; dates from Theresa Renfro research
new_people_to_create.notes: Son of John Renfro. Long-lived (died 1802 aged ~104).

new_people_to_create.evidence: Listed as child of John Renfro; birth 'Bet. 1698-1705', died 'Aft. 1752'
Listed as child of John Renfro; will dated 14 Nov 1772, probated 25 Mar 1776 Bedford Co VA
new_people_to_create.notes: Son of John Renfro. French & Indian War veteran (Lieutenant). Married Mary Randolph. Five sons were Revolutionary War officers.

new_people_to_create.evidence: Listed as child of John Renfro; death 'Bet. Feb 20 - Jun, 1789, Botetourt Co, Va'
new_people_to_create.notes: Son of John Renfro. Captain. Moved from James City Co to Botetourt Co.

new_people_to_create.evidence: Listed as child of John Renfro; died 'Aft. 1800'
new_people_to_create.notes: Youngest known child of John Renfro.

new_people_to_create.evidence: Cavaliers & Pioneers v1 p.546 - patent 6 May 1638
new_people_to_create.notes: Patented 500 acres at Chippokes Creek 1638. Transported Symon Renfro. Tony notes he 'is tied to JOHNSON research and land owners JOHNSON at Chippoakes Creek.'

relationships_to_add.evidence_summary: Tony's research lists Robert as child of Symon
John Renfro's will names wife Mary

locations_to_create.name: Chippokes Creek
locations_to_create.description: Creek in James City County where early Renfro and Johnson families settled. Jeremiah Dickenson patent 1638.
locations_to_create.notes: Tony notes Johnson families also owned land at Chippokes Creek

locations_to_create.name: James City County
locations_to_create.description: One of the original eight shires of Virginia. Location of early Renfro settlement.

locations_to_create.name: Welsh Tract
locations_to_create.description: Settlement area for Welsh Baptists who arrived 1701. John Renfro was a member of the Welsh Tract Baptist Church.
locations_to_create.notes: Community that connected Pennsylvania, Delaware, and Virginia settlers

locations_to_create.name: Bedford County
locations_to_create.description: Valley of Virginia county where Joseph Renfro settled. His will 1776 mentions Black Water.

locations_to_create.name: Botetourt County
locations_to_create.description: Valley of Virginia county where William Renfro (Captain) died 1789.

research_notes_not_evidence.note: Tony states Jeremiah Dickenson 'is tied to JOHNSON research and land owners JOHNSON at Chippoakes Creek' but does not specify which Johnsons or provide documentation.
research_notes_not_evidence.research_needed: Find Johnson patents/deeds at Chippokes Creek area in James City County records

research_notes_not_evidence.note: The relationship between Symon Renfro (1638 headright) and John Renfro (d.1728) is not explicitly documented. They could be father-son, grandfather-grandson, or unrelated.
research_notes_not_evidence.research_needed: Find documentation linking Symon Renfro to later Renfro generations

research_notes_not_evidence.note: Mary Randolph, wife of Joseph Renfro, may connect to the Randolph families of Tuckahoe Creek (same area as Michael Johnson). Tony mentions this connection but doesn't document it.
research_notes_not_evidence.research_needed: Identify which Randolph family Mary belonged to and if connected to Tuckahoe Creek Randolphs

key_findings: Symon Renfro arrived 1638 as headright of Jeremiah Dickenson - earliest documented Renfro
John Renfro (d.1728) had 8 children who dispersed across Virginia and North Carolina
Renfro family connected to Welsh Tract Baptist community (Pennsylvania/Delaware)
Joseph Renfro (b.1700) established in Bedford County; French & Indian War veteran
William Renfro (Captain) moved from James City to Botetourt County
Tony notes Johnson families also at Chippokes Creek - same area as early Renfros
